moves.4. Nbd2: Develop Knight and look for early trade
moves.4... d5 5. e3 a6: Looking to block Bishop b5 - but pointless move as if bishop did dvance then c6 would have worked and given black a stronger pawn structure. if situation did arise black could also block check with knight d7 and develop knight
moves.6. Bd3: bishop develops as normal and mounts pressure on knight
moves.6... Nd7: black misses fact exchange would favour white
moves.9... h6: looking to stop advancing bishops & knights
moves.10... Nb6: Knight eyeing up good out post on c4, also if queens moves A4 with a view to attack b2
moves.11. Bd3: Bishop retreats to cover, as light squares are looking crowded
moves.11... h5: Black looking to force a hole in whites king side cover... mistake as reopens g5 as an out post for white
moves.12. Ne5: although e5 works as well and reduces blacks options
moves.12... Nd7: exchange offered (and considered as 2 points up)
moves.13. Nxf7: Sac the knight and destroy blacks chances of castling, with a view to chase the king into submission
moves.13... Kxf7 14. Qf3: Queen moving in for attack, black must tread carefully not to lose queen.  Kg E8, BG6,Kg E7, BG5  black loses queen, if king not moved releaved check and queen taken with bishop.
moves.14... Kg8: Only place to go. Although this will limit blacks chances of getting h rook into action. Whites pieces are all developed whereas black is stuck on the back row.
moves.15. e4: White pressing forward, no real rush
moves.15... g6 16. e5: Pawn structure pointing towards stranded king,
moves.16... Rh7: Another mistake by black missing undefended pawn  g6
moves.17. Bxg6: King totally exposed, whites postion is much stronger although point wise it's level (3 pawns for a knight)
moves.17... Qh4: desperatly looking to fudge attack on H2
moves.18. Bxh7+: force king into open and get a nice bishop rook sac, not bad as light squares are tied up with blacks pawns
moves.18... Kxh7 19. Qe4+: again black must tread carfully as chance oof discovered attack & losing queen
moves.24... Qxf6 25. exf6: but win a passed pawn as a prize :)
moves.25... Bd7: black never rreally got bishop into play
moves.26. Rfe1: looking to bring the rook into action to force home pawn
moves.28... Nf4: black hope to catch out white with a fork on g6
moves.32. Rh7+ Ke8 33. Rh6: Black resigns although not a clear end insight the onward march of whites army would crush black...
